{{Infobox military unit |unit_name =1st Danish Artillery Battalion |native_name =1. Danske Artilleriafdeling |image = Emblem for 1st Danish Artillery Battalion.svg |caption = |dates =28 February 2014 (1684) |country ={{flag|Kingdom of Denmark}} |branch =[[File:Flag of Denmark (state).svg|25px]] [[Royal Danish Army]] |type = |role = |size =500 |command_structure =[[Army Combat and Fire Support Center]] |current_commander =[[Lieutenant Colonel]] Poul-Erik Andersen |garrison =[[Oksbøl]] |ceremonial_chief =[[Margrethe II of Denmark|HM The Queen of Denmark]] |colonel_of_the_regiment=Ole Bering |nickname =1DAA |patron = |motto =''Ingen tvivl, ingen tøven'' (No doubt, no hesitation) |colors =[[File:New Danish Artillery Regiment Stable belt.png|80px]] | colors_label =Regimental belt |march = |mascot =[[Saint Barbara]][http://www.artilleriet.dk/artikel/1357.htm artilleriet.dk: Skt. Barbara] |battles =Battle of Nybøl (28 May 1848)
[[Battle of Fredericia]] (6 July 1849)
[[Battle of Isted]] (25 July 1850)
Battle of Mysunde (12 September 1850)
Battle of Mysunde 2 February 1864
Battle of Dybbøl (18 April 1864) |notable_commanders = |anniversaries = }} The '''1st Danish Artillery Battalion''' ({{lang-da|1. Danske Artilleriafdeling, 1DAA}}) is a part of [[Army Combat and Fire Support Center]] and was created after under the [[Danish Defence Agreement 2013-2017]], after the ''[[Danish Artillery Regiment]]'' was disbanded. It is the only remaining military unit in the [[Royal Danish Army|Danish Army]] that is involved with artillery, and is therefore the bearer of the traditions of the former regiment and can trace its roots back to 1684.{{cite web|title=Nye myndigheder, nye baretmærker og farver|url=http://forsvaret.dk/HST/Nyt%20og%20Presse/forlig2013-17/Pages/Nyemyndigheder,nyebaretm%C3%A6rkerogfarver.aspx|website=Forsvaret.dk|language=Danish|access-date=2015-10-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117024535/http://forsvaret.dk/HST/Nyt%20og%20Presse/forlig2013-17/Pages/Nyemyndigheder,nyebaretm%C3%A6rkerogfarver.aspx|archive-date=2015-11-17|dead-url=yes|df=}} The battalion is divided into a number of [[Artillery battery|batteries]] with around 500 personnel in total.[http://forsvaret.dk/HST/om_haeren/Pages/default.aspx forsvaret.dk: om Hæren] 1 DAA provides fielding and training of the army's ability to plan, deploy, manage and operate fire-support such as [[M109_howitzer#M109A3_and_M109A3B|howitzer]] and [[Soltam K6|heavy mortars]] at different tactical levels.[http://www.artilleriet.dk/1DAA/ artilleriet.dk: 1 DAA] ==See also== *[[Royal Danish Army]] *[[Danish Artillery Regiment]] *[[Equipment of the Royal Danish Army#Artillery|Equipment of the Royal Danish Army]] *[[Military of Denmark]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://forsvaret.dk/HKIC/Pages/default.aspx forsvaret.dk/HKIC - Hærens kamp- og ildstøttecenter] * [http://www.artilleriet.dk/ artilleriet.dk] [[Category:Artillery regiments of Denmark]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 2014]] [[Category:2014 establishments in Denmark]] {{Military of Denmark}} {{Denmark-stub}} {{europe-mil-stub}} {{Mil-unit-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox military unit | unit_name = 6th Division | native_name= ''6. Division'' | image = | caption = | dates = 1920–1938 | country = {{flag|Austria}} | branch = [[Austrian Bundesheer]] | type = [[Light infantry]] | role = [[Mountain warfare]] | size = | garrison =[[Innsbruck]] | garrison_label =Headquarters | motto = | colors = | colors_label = | march = | battles = | anniversaries = | decorations = | battle_honours = | battle_honours_label = | notable_commanders = [[Eugen Beyer]] }} The '''6th Division''' ({{lang-de|6. Division}}; before 1935 the '''6th Brigade''', ''6. Brigade'') was a division of [[mountain warfare|alpine troops]] in the [[Austrian Bundesheer]] of the [[First Austrian Republic]]. Headquartered in [[Innsbruck]], it drew from [[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]], [[Salzburg (state)|Salzburg]], [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]], and [[Vorarlberg]]. After the [[Anschluss]] of Austria by Nazi Germany in 1938, it was folded into the [[2nd Mountain Division (Wehrmacht)|2nd Mountain Division]] of the [[Wehrmacht]]. [[Eugen Beyer]] was its last commander.
The units permanently assigned to the division were: * Divisional Staff (Innsbruck) * ''Tiroler Jägerregiment'' (Innsbruck) * ''Tiroler Landesschützenregiment Dr. Dollfuß'' ([[Solbad Hall]] and [[Kufstein]]) * ''Vorarlberger Alpenjägerbataillon Nr. 4'' ([[Bregenz]] and [[Bludenz]]) * ''Tiroler und Vorarlberger Leichtes Artillerieregiment Nr. 6'' (Innsbruck) * ''Telegraphen-Bataillon 6'' (Innsbruck) * ''Divisions-Kraftfahr-Abteilung 6'' (Bregenz)
[[Category:Military units and formations of Austria]]
{{mil-unit-stub}} {{Austria-stub}}

{{Infobox legislation |short_title = Andorran Citizenship Act |legislature = [[Parliament of Andorra]] |image = Coat of arms of Andorra.svg |imagesize = |imagealt = |caption = |long_title = An Act relating to Andorran citizenship |citation = |territorial_extent = |enacted_by = [[Government of Andorra]] |date_enacted = |date_passed = |enacted_by2 = |date_enacted2 = |date_passed2 = |date_assented = |royal_assent = |date_signed = |signed_by = |date_commenced = |date_of_expiry = |date_repealed = |administered_by = |bill = |bill_citation = |bill_date = |introduced_by = |1st_reading = |2nd_reading = |3rd_reading = |conf_committee_passed = |committee_report = |bill2 = |bill_citation2 = |bill_date2 = |introduced_by2 = |1st_reading2 = |2nd_reading2 = |3rd_reading2 = |conf_committee_passed2 = |committee_report2 = |date_conf_committee = |white_paper = |amendments = |repeals = |related_legislation = |summary = |keywords = |status = current }}
'''Andorran nationality law''' is based primarily on the principle of [[jus sanguinis]].
==Eligibility for Andorran citizenship==
===By descent===
Children born to recognised parents who were Andorran citizens at the time of birth (regardless of the place of birth) are eligible for Andorran citizenship.
===By birth===
Children born in [[Andorra]] under any one of the following conditions are eligible for Andorran citizenship:
* born to parents of whom either one (or both) was born in Andorra and was living permanently and principally in Andorra at the time of birth * born to non-Andorran parents who were living permanently and principally in Andorra for at least 10 years at the time of birth
===By naturalisation===
Those seeking to become Andorran citizens via [[naturalisation]] are required to fulfill the following criteria:
* they must renounce existing foreign citizenships * they must have resided in Andorra permanently for at least ten years if the applicant has spent all of his mandatory education in Andorra or for at least 20 years if he/she can prove his/her integration into Andorran society
==Loss of citizenship==
If an Andorran citizen serves in the armed forces or government of another country or takes up a foreign citizenship, he/she automatically forfeits his/her Andorran citizenship.
Former Andorran citizens may restore their former citizenship if their request to the government is successful.
Any Andorran may live in France without requesting a visa.<ref>https://www.service-public.fr/particuliers/vosdroits/F16162</ref>
==Dual nationality==
[[Multiple citizenship|Dual nationality]] is strictly forbidden by Andorran law. On the other hand, Spanish law, though, recognizes dual nationality with Andorra.<ref>http://www.mjusticia.gob.es/cs/Satellite/Portal/es/areas-tematicas/nacionalidad/nacionalidad/tener-doble-nacionalidad "citizens of (...) Andorra should not renounce to their previous nationality"</ref>
==See also== *[[Andorran passport]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110531145510/http://www.amb-andorre.ad/nationalite.html Information page about Andorran nationality from the Andorran Embassy in Paris]
{{Nationality laws}}
[[Category:Andorran law]] [[Category:Nationality law]]
{{Andorra-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Caspe |image= |caption= |partof=the [[Spanish Civil War]] |date=March 16–17, 1938 |place=[[Caspe]], [[Aragon]], Spain |result=Nationalist victory |combatant1={{flagicon image|Flag of Spain 1931 1939.svg}} [[Second Spanish Republic|Spanish Republic]] |combatant2={{flag|Nationalist Spain|1938}} |commander1= ? |commander2= {{flagicon|Nationalist Spain|1938}}Fernando Barron
{{flagicon|Nationalist Spain|1938}}[[Agustín Muñoz Grandes]]
{{flagicon|Nationalist Spain|1938}}Bautista Sánchez |strength1=XV International Brigade |strength2= three divisions |casualties1= |casualties2=}} {{Campaignbox Spanish Civil War}} The '''Battle of Caspe''' took place during the [[Aragon Offensive]] of the [[Spanish Civil War]] in 16–17 March 1938. ==Background== After the [[Battle of Teruel]], the [[Spanish Republican Army|Republican Army]] in Aragon was exhausted and badly equipped. In March 1938 a huge Nationalist force of 150,000 men and more than 900 planes started an offensive in Aragon, breaking the Republican front. Most of the units of the Republican Army fled and the retreat became a rout, but in some points others fought bravely.Beevor, Antony. (2006). ''The Battle for Spain. The Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939.'' Penguin Books. London. pp.324-325 ==Battle of Caspe.== On 9 March the Nationalists advanced 36 kilometres, on 10 March they occupied [[Belchite]] held by the [[XV International Brigade]],Thomas, Hugh. (2001). ''The Spanish Civil War.'' Penguin Books. London. p.777 and pushed forward to [[Caspe]].Beevor, Antony. (2006). ''The Battle for Spain. The Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939.'' Penguin Books. London. p.325 Then, the commander in chief of the Republican army, [[Vicente Rojo Lluch|Vicente Rojo]] ordered to establish a defensive line with the town of Caspe at its centre. By 16 March three Nationalist divisions of the Varela’s Army, led by [[Fernando Barron|Fernando Barrón]], Muñoz Grandes and Bautista Sánchez, surrounded the town held by the XV International Brigade. The Brigade fought with great valour, but after two days of heavy fighting Caspe fell to the Nationalists.Thomas, Hugh. (2001). ''The Spanish Civil War.'' Penguin Books. London. p.778 ==Aftermath== The Nationalists continued their advance and by 3 April occupied [[Lérida]].Beevor, Antony. (2006). ''The Battle for Spain. The Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939.'' Penguin Books. London. p.326 ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *Beevor, Antony. ''The Battle for Spain. The Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939.'' Penguin Books. 2006. London. {{ISBN|978-0-14-303765-1}}. *Thomas, Hugh. ''The Spanish Civil War.'' Penguin Books. 2001. London. {{ISBN|978-0-14-101161-5}} {{coord missing|Spain}} [[Category:Battles of the Spanish Civil War|Caspe]] [[Category:1938 in Spain]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1938|Caspe]] [[Category:Province of Zaragoza]] [[Category:March 1938 events]] {{Spain-stub}}

{{Expand Spanish|Batalla de la Ciudad Universitaria de Madrid|topic=hist|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Battle of Ciudad Universitaria | image = | caption = Map of the attack of the Ciudad Universitaria on 15–18 November 1936 | partof = the [[Siege of Madrid]], [[Spanish Civil War]] | date = 15–23 November 1936 | place = [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] | result = Strategic Republican victory | combatant1 = {{flagicon|Spain|1931}} [[Spanish Republic]]
[[File:Flag of the International Brigades.svg|23px]] [[International Brigades]]
[[File:Bandera CNT-FAI.png|23px]] [[Durruti Column]] | combatant2 = {{flagicon|Nationalist Spain|1936}} [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist Spain]] | commander1 = [[José Miaja Menant]]
[[Vicente Rojo Lluch|Vicente Rojo]]
[[Carlos Romero Giménez]]
[[José Gallego Pérez]]
[[Emilio Kléber]]
[[Máté Zalka|Paul Lukács]]
[[Buenaventura Durruti|José B. Durruti]]{{KIA}} | commander2 = [[Francisco Franco]]
[[Carlos Asensio Cabanillas|Asensio Cabanillas]]
[[Francisco Delgado Serrano|Francisco Delgado]] | strength1 = Central Army
• 11,000
International Brigades
• 1,800
Columna Durruti
• 1,400 militiamen | strength2 = [[Army of Africa (Spain)|Army of Africa]]
• 3,000 regulares
• 18 tanks | casualties1 = high | casualties2 = high | campaignbox ={{Campaignbox Spanish Civil War}}}} The '''Battle of Ciudad Universitaria''' took place around the campus of the [[Complutense University of Madrid]] between 15 and 23 November 1936, during the [[Spanish Civil War]]. ==History== The battle took place in the first months of the Civil War in the [[University City of Madrid]], the new campus of Madrid’s Complutense University. It lasted for about a week, between 15 and 23 November 1936, following which the front stabilized until the end of the war. The aim of the Republican militias was the defence of the capital at any price, to achieve which they needed to stop the progress of the columns at the command of General Varela and avoid the fall of Madrid into rebel hands.[[Vicente Rojo Lluch]], ''Así fue la defensa de Madrid: aportación a la historia de la Guerra de España, 1936–1939'' (1st edition). México (1967). Ediciones Era. p. 55. The aim of the attacking armies of the military rebellion on the other hand was to "take the city" within the shortest possible period of time. This battle signalled the beginning of a new phase in the Spanish Civil war, for until then the [[Francoist]] troops had been advancing relatively unopposed across Spain, conquering large swathes of territory in a few months. But here, at the Ciudad Universitaria, for the first time, they encountered fierce and relentless opposition.Jorge Martínez Reverte (2004). ''La Batalla de Madrid'' (1st edition). Barcelona: Crítica. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord|40|26|38|N|3|43|34|W|type:event_source:kolossus-eswiki|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Category:Battles of the Spanish Civil War|Ciudad Universitaria]] [[Category:1936 in Spain]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1936|Ciudad Universitaria]] [[Category:Urban warfare|Ciudad Universitaria]] [[Category:Attacks on schools]] [[Category:Complutense University of Madrid]] [[Category:November 1936 events]] [[Category:20th century in Madrid]] {{commons}} {{Spain-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox aviator | name = DeLloyd Thompson | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date =1888<!--Hundt source indicates 26 in 1914 --><ref name=hundt /> | birth_place = [[Buffalo Township, Washington County, Pennsylvania]] | death_date = 1949<ref name=hundt /> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LATITUDE|LONGITUDE|type:landmark}} --> | education = | spouse = | relatives = | known_for = | memorials = }} '''DeLoyd "Dutch" Thompson''' was a pioneering aviator of the early 20th century.
He was born in 1888<!--Hundt source indicates 26 in 1914 --> and grew up in [[Buffalo Township, Washington County, Pennsylvania]].<ref name=hundt /> As a pilot, he was part of the tradition of "[[Barnstorming|exhibition]]" pilots, travelling throughout countrysides and entertaining with their aeronautical feats.<ref name=hundt>{{cite news |last=Hundt |first=Brad |title=A century ago, a Washington man changed aviation |newspaper=[[Observer-Reporter]] |date=August 2, 2014 |url=http://www.observer-reporter.com/article/20140802/NEWS01/140809905 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VVJseFGT?url=http://www.observer-reporter.com/article/20140802/NEWS01/140809905 |archivedate=January 11, 2015 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On August 6, 1914, Thompson set the [[flight altitude record]] by flying to a height of {{convert|15,256|ft|m}} over [[Overland Park, Kansas]] in his Day-Gyro plane.<ref name=hundt /> Because of the coldness at that altitude, he wore a sheepskin suit.<ref name=hundt /> When the plane ran out of fuel, he executed a spiral glide maneuver to return to earth.<ref name=hundt /> This feat, which placed him at the altitude of modern [[turboprop]] planes, happened only 10 years after the [[Wright brothers]]' first flight.<ref name=hundt /> However, because of the advances in flight technology, the record did not last long.<ref name=hundt />
In 1916, during the run-up to American involvement in [[World War I]], he tried to raise American awareness of the aerial warfare and to encourage greater protections for the East Coast, by launching [[pyrotechnics]] over [[Washington, D.C.]] .<ref name=hundt /> He dropped packets reading, "This 'Bomb' is Harmless. Suppose it had contained [[Nitroglycerin|Nitro-Glycerine]] and was hurled by the ''[[Central Powers|enemy]]'' instead of by DeLloyd Thompson, who flies the American Flag? WAKE UP AND PREPARE"<ref name=hundt />
That same year, he broke the air speed record over Long Island by traveling 108.4 mph.<ref name=miller /> He was the second American to [[Aerobatic loop|loop an airplane]].<ref name=m1969 /> He invented the undertaker's drop, a famous airplane maneuver.<ref name=m1969 /> He was the second aviator in the world to sky-write with an airplane.<ref name=m1969 />
In 1937, developed and constructed the DeLloydCabinaire, a 2 seat monoplane, but that venture failed, due in part to the continuing [[Great Depression]], and only 2 were ever built.<ref name=hundt /><ref name=miller /> That year, his last flight was a demonstration of that plane.<ref name=miller />
Following his aeronautical career, he made an unsuccessful bid to become mayor of [[Washington, Pennsylvania]] in 1939.<ref name=hundt /> He also became the owner of a coal mine and worked as a construction contractor<ref name=hundt /> He was in an automobile accident on [[U.S. Route 40 in Pennsylvania]] 1945.<ref name=hundt /> He died in Washington 1949 from heart failure.<ref name=hundt />
[[File:DeLloyd Thompson plaque at Washington County Airport 1949.jpg|thumb|lef|150px|The plaque, created by [[Early Birds of Aviation]], which was installed at the [[Washington County Airport (Pennsylvania)|Washington County Airport]] in 1949.]] On July 13, 1949, the DeLoyd Thompson Memorial Gates were dedicated at the [[Washington County Airport (Pennsylvania)|Washington County Airport]].<ref name=m1969 /> The event, which was attended by 5,000, was marked with an [[airshow]] conducted by the [[Early Birds of Aviation]].<ref name=miller /><ref name=m1969>{{cite news | title =Memorial for Dutch Thompson | newspaper =[[Observer-Reporter]] | date =September 8, 1969 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19690908&id=KmteAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y2ENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1654,675652 | accessdate =February 15, 2015 }}</ref>
Eventually, the grounds of the airport outgrew the gates.<ref name=miller /> In 1969, the plates from the gate were refurbished and airport administration building.<ref name=miller>{{cite news |last=Miller |first=Barbara |title=Part of pioneer aviator’s legacy may return to Washington County Airport |newspaper=[[Observer-Reporter]] |date=November 25, 2013 |url=http://www.observer-reporter.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20131125/NEWS01/131129514 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215043544/http://www.observer-reporter.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20131125%2FNEWS01%2F131129514 |archivedate=February 15, 2015 |accessdate=February 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> However, the plates were removed from the grounds, and were at risk of being sold for scrap before being rescued by Margaret Thompson, DeLoyd's daughter-in-law.<ref name=miller /> They eventually were placed in the custody of the Washington County Historical Society at the [[F. Julius LeMoyne House]].<ref name=hundt /> In 2013 and 2014, Clay Kilgore, executive director of the Washington County Historical Society, led an effort to restore the plaques to the airport.<ref name=hundt />
==See also == *[[1914 in aviation]] *[[Early Birds of Aviation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://earlyaviators.com/ethompso.htm DAVID LLOYD "DUTCH" TH0MPSON -1949 AKA DeLloyd Thompson] at [[Early Birds of Aviation]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Thompson, Delloyd}} [[Category:1888 births]] [[Category:1949 deaths]] [[Category:People from Washington County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Members of the Early Birds of Aviation]] [[Category:Aviators from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Flight speed record holders]]

revision.text:
The '''Deciates''' (Δεκιῆται) were a [[Ligures|Ligurian]] tribe in the first few centuries BC. They lived in the [[Antibes]] area of what is now France, west of the river [[Var River|Var]] (Smith, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text.jsp?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0064:alphabetic%20letter=D:entry%20group=2:entry=deciates entry on Deciátes]; Cosson, pp. 20–23). The border with the Ligurian [[Oxybii]] (Ὀξύβιοι) being to the west of [[Antibes|Antipolis]] and east of [[Fréjus|Forum Julii]] (Smith, [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text.jsp?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0064%3Aalphabetic+letter%3DO%3Aentry%3Doxybii&highlight= entry on Oxybii]). The Deciates had a town in the area, ''oppidum Deciatum'' but this was not Antibes itself (Pliny the Elder, Chorographia, 2.69):
:''In litoribus aliquot sunt cum aliquis nominibus loca: ceterum rarae urbes quia rari portus, et omnis plaga austro atque africo exposita est. Nicaea tangit Alpes, tangit oppidum Deciatum, tangit Antipolis.''
==References== *Cosson, Pierre (1995) ''Civitas Antipolitana: Histoire du Municipe Romain d'Antipolis''.Nice, Serre Editeur. {{ISBN|2-86410-219-6}} *Pliny the Elder, Chorographia, II.69 *Smith, William (1854) ''Dictionary of Greek and Roman Geography''.
[[Category:Ligures]]
{{Europe-ethno-group-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Ireland}} "Dreamin'" | image = | caption = | year = 1995 | country = Ireland | artist = Eddie Friel | as = | with = | language = English | languages = | composer = Richard Abbott, Barry Woods | lyricist = Richard Abbott, Barry Woods | conductor = [[Noel Kelehan]] | place = 14th | points = 44 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1995ie from Diggiloo Thrush] | clip = [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=93tdTbDjo0o from YouTube] | prev = Rock 'n' Roll Kids | prev_link = Rock 'n' Roll Kids | next = The Voice | next_link = The Voice (Eimear Quinn song) }} '''"Dreamin'"''' was the [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1995]], performed in [[English language|English]] by [[Eddie Friel]].
The song is a ballad, with Friel singing about the dream he is having and how free he feels in it before he awakes.
The song was performed second on the night, following [[Poland]]'s [[Justyna]] with "[[Sama (song)|Sama]]" and preceding [[Germany]]'s [[Stone & Stone]] with "[[Verliebt in Dich]]". At the close of voting, it had received 44 points, placing 14th in a field of 23. This result was something of a surprise, as Ireland had won the previous 3 Contests (and would in fact go on to win the next one).
The song caused some controversy in the lead-up to the contest as it was discovered to be very similar to a [[Julie Felix]] song called "Moonlight". The second-placed song in the national final was for a while considered for entry, until it was announced that "Dreamin'" could go through.
It was succeeded as [[Republic of Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Irish representative]] in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996|1996 contest]] by [[Eimear Quinn]] with "[[The Voice (Eimear Quinn song)|The Voice]]" which went on to win the contest for Ireland yet again.
{{Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1995}}
[[Category:Eurovision songs of Ireland]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1995]] [[Category:1995 songs]]
{{ireland-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=August 2011}} This is an overview of the '''economy of [[Monaco]]'''. Monaco, situated on the French coast of the [[Mediterranean Sea]], is a popular resort, attracting tourists to its casino and pleasant climate.
The [[Principality]] has successfully sought to diversify into services and small, high-value-added, nonpolluting industries. The state has no [[income tax]] and low business taxes and thrives as a [[tax haven]] both for individuals who have established residence and for foreign companies that have set up businesses and offices. The state retains [[Monopoly|monopolies]] in a number of sectors, including tobacco, the telephone network, and the postal service.
Though official economic statistics are not published, year 2011 estimates place the national product at $5.748 billion and the per capita income at $188,409. The unemployment rate is 2%, as of 2012.[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mn.html]
Living standards are high and roughly comparable to those in the prosperous French metropolitan areas. Monaco does not publish national income figures; the estimates below are extremely rough. [[File: Rubber discs for suctions-5.jpg|thumbnail|right|Denture adhesion rings made in Monaco, Early to Mid 20th Century]]
==Background== Economic development was spurred in the late 19th century with the opening of the rail link to France and a [[Monte Carlo Casino|casino]]. Monaco's economy is now primarily geared toward finance, commerce, and tourism.
==Modern times== Low taxes have drawn many foreign companies to Monaco and account for around 75% of the $5.748 billion annual GDP income in (2011). Similarly, tourism accounts for close to 15% of the annual revenue, as the Principality of Monaco also has been a major center for tourism ever since the famed [[Monte Carlo Casino]], which was established in 1856. The casino is alluded to in the [[ABBA]] song ''[[Money, Money, Money]]''.
Financial and insurance activities, along with scientific and technical activities are main contributors to GDP of Monaco. <ref>[http://www.monacostatistics.mc/Economy-and-Finance/ GDP Gross Domestic Product]</ref> Banking sector of Monaco is rather large: in 2015 consolidated banking assets 8.42 times exceeded the country's GDP. Banks operating in Monaco traditionally specialize in private banking, asset and wealth management services.<ref>[https://thebanks.eu/articles/banks-in-Monaco Banks in Monaco]</ref>
An economic and customs union with France governs customs, postal services, telecommunications, and banking in Monaco. Before the [[euro]], Monaco used the [[French franc]]. Now part of the [[Eurozone]], but not the EU, Monaco mints [[Monegasque euro coins|its own euro coins]].
All residents pay tax in the form of 19.6% [[value-added tax]] on all goods and services.<ref>Genta, Evelyne (Monaco Ambassador to the UK) ''Monaco Might Not Charge Residents Income Tax, But it's No Tax Haven'' ''The Telegraph'' 16 Feb 2010</ref>
Monaco is noted for its activity in the field of marine sciences. Its [[Oceanographic Museum]], formerly directed by [[Jacques-Yves Cousteau]], is one of the most renowned institutions of its kind in the world. Monaco imports and exports products and services from all over the world. There is no commercial agriculture in Monaco; it is 100% urban.
==Tax haven== Monaco levies no income tax on individuals. The absence of a personal income tax in the [[principality]], has attracted to it a considerable number of wealthy "tax refugee" residents from European countries who derive the majority of their income from activity outside Monaco; celebrities such as Formula One drivers attract most of the attention, but the vast majority of them are less well-known business people.
In 2000, a report by the French parliamentarians, Arnaud Montebourg and Vincent Peillon, alleged that Monaco had lax policies with respect to money laundering, including within its famed casino, and that the government of Monaco had been placing political pressure on the judiciary so that alleged crimes were not properly investigated.
In 1998, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) issued a first report on the consequences of the tax havens' financial systems. Monaco did not appear in the list of these territories until 2004, when OECD became indignant regarding the Monegasque situation and denounced it in its last report, as well as Andorra, Liechtenstein, Liberia and the Marshall Islands, underlining its lack of co-operation as regards to financial information disclosure and availability.
In 2000, the Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering (FATF) stated: "The anti-money laundering system in Monaco is comprehensive. However, difficulties have been encountered with Monaco by countries in international investigations on serious crimes that appear to be linked also with tax matters. In addition, the FIU of Monaco (SICCFIN) suffers a great lack of adequate resources. The authorities of Monaco have stated that they will provide additional resources to SICCFIN." The Principality is no longer blamed in the 2005 FATF report, as well as all other territories. However, since 2003, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has identified Monaco, along with 36 other territories, as a tax haven.
The Council of Europe also decided to issue reports naming tax havens. Twenty-two territories, including Monaco, were thus evaluated between 1998 and 2000 on a first round. Monaco is the only territory that refuses to perform the second round, initially forecast between 2001 and 2003, whereas the 21 other territories are implementing the third and last round, planned between 2005 and 2007.
==See also== *[[Economy of Europe]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://money.guardian.co.uk/tax/story/0,1456,1152758,00.html Guardian article on tax havens, discussion of Monaco] * [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mn.html CIA World Factbook entry on Monaco] * [http://www.monaco-consulate.com/?page_id=887 Tax system of Monaco]

[[File:Eska Music Awards 2011 in Katowice (Poland).jpg|thumb|Eska Music Awards 2011]] '''Eska Music Awards''' (EMA) is a Polish awards ceremony for national and international music launched in 2002 by [[Radio Eska]]. Amongst the award winners are [[Jamelia]], [[Alexis Jordan]], [[t.A.T.u.]], [[3 Doors Down]], [[The Rasmus]], [[Mattafix]], [[Melanie C]], [[Sugababes]], [[Razorlight]], [[September (singer)|September]], [[Sarsa (singer)|Sarsa]], [[Craig David]], [[Margaret (singer)|Margaret]], [[The Killers]], [[Matt Pokora]], [[Katy Perry]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Sunrise Avenue]], [[OneRepublic]], [[White Lies (band)|White Lies]], [[Kesha]], [[Basshunter]], [[Inna]], [[David Guetta]], [[Nelly Furtado]], [[Adam Lambert]], [[Ed Sheeran]] and more. ==2017 Eska Music Awards == {{Infobox award|name=Eska Music Awards 2017|image=Eska Music Awards 2017.jpg|date=17 June 2017|location=[[Azoty Arena]], [[Szczecin]]|host=Krzysztof ''Jankes'' Jankowski
Paulina Chylewska|network=[[TVP1]]
[[Radio Eska]]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox organization |name = Euro-Atlantic Center |image_border = |image = Euro-Atlantic center.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = |abbreviation = EAC |established = 1999 |type = [[non-governmental organization]] |headquarters = Kuzmányho 3, 974 01 Banská Bystrica, [[Slovakia]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |website = [http://eac.sk www.eac.sk] }} The '''Euro-Atlantic Center (EAC) '''is a independent [[Slovakia|Slovak]] [[non-governmental organization]] uniting young professionals and students active in the field of international relations, Slovak foreign policy and security. The EAC was founded in 1999 by a group of students from Banská Bystrica, Slovakia. The headquarters of the organization is located at the Faculty of Political Science and International Relations of the [[Matej Bel University]] in Banská Bystrica. Since 2008, the EAC is also active at the [[University of Economics in Bratislava]], where the regional bureau is located.
== Aims == The EAC has two main goals: # ''Towards its members'' - to practically prepare students for their future careers by developing their teamwork, managerial, journalistic, analytical and networking skills. #''Towards the public'' - inform, educate and raise the awareness of young people and the general public about topics related to international and national security, as well as about international affairs focusing on NATO and the European Union.
== Projects == *''The Slovak Security Forum'' - The project represents Slovakia’s second biggest security conference, which traditionally opens the Slovak diplomatic season. Moreover, it represents one of the main pillars of the dialogue on national security in Slovakia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teraz.sk/slovensko/lparizekslovensko-nechce-byt-len-konzume/283710-clanok.html |title= Slovenské bezpečnostné fórum |publisher=TASR |date= |accessdate=2018-07-09 }}</ref> *''The Visegrad Youth Forum'' - The project consists of several phases, which culminate in a three-day conference in Banská Bystrica. The entire project is organized and carried out in English with the participation of university students from all V4 member states. During the conference participants take part in a welcoming reception, panel discussions, workshops, full-day simulation and a field trip near Banska Bystrica. *''Speaking Tours'' - Each year, the EAC embarks on a journey to a number of selected Slovak high schools and universities, aiming to bring important topics closer to a broader audience. Each past editions of the project focused on different main topics. #2014 - This is NATO - on the occasion of the 10th anniversary of the entry of the Slovak Republic to NATO, #2015 - SK PRESS 2016 - the priorities of the Slovak Presidency of the Council of the European Union, #2016 - Security challenges - current security challenges, #2017 - Priorities of Foreign Policy of the Slovak Republic. *Open Embassy – A series of meetings between students and employees of respective embassies present in Slovakia. Through this visit, they can get information on the country's current foreign policy. *Current issues / Discussion clubs *Education is the Future * #ONTHETABLE
==Notes== {{reflist}}
== External links == * http://vyf.eac.sk * http://sbf.eac.sk * https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7DsvGzLViRc interview with EAC members about EAC and VYF 2013 (in slovak language) * https://www.facebook.com/EACenter?fref=ts (Facebook page)

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} '''External association''' was a hypothetical relationship between [[Ireland]] and the [[British Commonwealth]] proposed by [[Éamon de Valera]] in 1921–22, whereby Ireland would be a [[sovereign state]] associated with, but not a member of, the Commonwealth; the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|British monarch]] would be head of the association, but not [[head of state]] of Ireland. De Valera proposed external association as a compromise between [[isolationism|isolationist]] [[Irish republicanism]] on the one hand and [[Dominion]] status on the other.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hawkings|first=M. A.|date=March 1981|title=Defence and the Role of Erskine Childers in the Treaty Negotiations of 1921|journal=Irish Historical Studies |volume=22|issue=87|pages=251–270: 253 |jstor=30075034}}</ref> Whereas a full republic could not be a member of the Commonwealth until the [[London Declaration]] of 1949, a Dominion could not be fully independent until the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]].
External association was never implemented as such; however, de Valera's 1930s diplomacy reflected similar ideas, as did the Commonwealth's London Declaration.
==Origins== Troy D. Davis suggests de Valera's thinking on external association was influenced, during his tour of the United States in 1919–20, by the US [[Sugar Intervention]] in Cuba.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Davis|first=Troy D.|date=Spring 2006|title=Eamon de Valéra's Political Education: The American Tour of 1919-20|journal=New Hibernia Review / Iris Éireannach Nua|publisher=University of St. Thomas (Center for Irish Studies)|volume=10|issue=1|pages=65–78|jstor=20646520|doi=10.1353/nhr.2006.0019}}</ref> [[Nicholas Mansergh]] traces the first reference to "external association" to 27 July 1921, preceding a proposal by de Valera on 10 August for a [[treaty of free association]] between the [[Irish Republic]] and Great Britain.<ref>Mansergh 1991, p.166</ref> De Valera told Mansergh in 1965 that the idea of external association came to him "one morning as he was tying his bootlaces", shortly after [[Jan Smuts]]' exploratory visit following the June 1921 ceasefire which ended the [[Irish War of Independence|Anglo-Irish War]] (later called the Irish War of Independence).<ref>Mansergh 1997, pp.191–192</ref> In September 1921, [[David Lloyd George]], the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|UK prime minister]], proposed negotiations into "how the association of Ireland with the community of nations known as the British Empire may best be reconciled with Irish national aspirations".<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.dippam.ac.uk/eppi/documents/22769/page/639943 |title=Further Correspondence Relating to the Proposals of His Majesty's Government for an Irish Settlement. [In Continuation of the Correspondence contained in Cmd. 1470.] |year=1921 |series=[[Command paper]]s |volume=Cmd.1539 |publisher=HMSO |page=11 |accessdate=17 February 2017 |location=London}}</ref> De Valera accepted and explained his concept of external association to the plenipotentiaries sent to London. Their head, [[Arthur Griffith]], later said de Valera told him the idea was to get out of the "straitjacket of the Republic" while "bringing Cathal along", referring to [[Cathal Brugha]], the staunchest republican in the [[Dáil ministry]].<ref name="Coogan2002">{{cite book|last=Coogan|first=Tim Pat|title=Michael Collins: The Man Who Made Ireland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xscRAhBt2JgC&pg=PA231|accessdate=18 August 2012|date=17 May 2002|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9780312295110|page=231}}</ref>
==Document No. 2== The British ministers negotiating with the Irish plenipotentiaries rejected the idea of external association, and the [[Anglo-Irish Treaty]] the two sides signed on 6 December 1921 provided for an [[Irish Free State]] with the same status as the [[Dominion of Canada]]. De Valera opposed this, and in the [[Second Dáil]] debate on the Treaty offered his alternative "Document No. 2", of which articles 2 to 6 described the "Terms of Association":<ref>{{cite web|url=http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1922/01/10/00025.asp#N8 |title=Appendix 18: The President's alternative proposals|date=10 January 1922|work=Treaty debates|publisher=Oireachtas|accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref>
#<li value="2"> That, for purposes of common concern, Ireland shall be associated with the States of the British Commonwealth, viz: the Kingdom of Great Britain, the Dominion of Canada, the [[Commonwealth of Australia]], the [[Dominion of New Zealand]], and the [[Union of South Africa]]. # That when acting as an associate the rights, status, and privileges of Ireland shall be in no respect less than those enjoyed by any of the component States of the British Commonwealth. # That the matters of "common concern" shall include Defence, Peace and War, Political Treaties, and all matters now treated as of common concern amongst the States of the British Commonwealth, and that in these matters there shall be between Ireland and the States of the British Commonwealth "such concerted action founded on consultation as the several Governments may determine". # That in virtue of this association of Ireland with the States of the British Commonwealth citizens of Ireland in any of these States shall not be subject to any disabilities which a citizen of one of the component States of the British Commonwealth would not be subject to, and reciprocally for citizens of these States in Ireland. # That, for purposes of the Association, Ireland shall recognise His Britannic Majesty as head of the Association.
De Valera, a former mathematics teacher, used [[Venn diagram]]s and other graphs to illustrate the relationships he envisaged between Ireland and the Commonwealth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/Extras/De_Valera_theory.html|title=De Valera's theory of external association|last=Ní Shúilleabháin|first=Cáit|work=The MacTutor History of Mathematics archive|publisher=School of Mathematics and Statistics|accessdate=5 June 2013|location=University of St Andrews}}</ref> Commentators have suggested the putative virtues of his proposal were too subtle and abstract to appeal to either supporters of the Treaty or republicans opposed to it.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Akenson|first=D. H.|date=April 1971|title=Was De Valera a Republican?|journal=The Review of Politics|publisher=Cambridge University Press|volume=33|issue=2|pages=233–253|jstor=1406252|doi=10.1017/s0034670500012250}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Curran|first=Joseph M.|date=Spring 1968|title=The Consolidation of the Irish Revolution, 1921-1923: The Free Staters|journal=Irish University Review|volume=5|issue=1|pages=36–50|jstor=25504816}}</ref> A journalist reporting on the Dáil debate said of de Valera's presentation, "One felt, however, we were entering the region of pure [[casuistry]], nebulous, unpalpable and unreal."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/freestateorrepub00burcuoft#page/32/mode/1up |page=32 |title=Free state or republic? Pen pictures of the historic treaty session of Dáil Éireann |first=Pádraig |last=De Búrca |author2=John F. Boyle |publisher=Talbot Press |year=1922 }}</ref>
==Rejection of association== The Dáil [[Anglo-Irish Treaty Dáil vote|voted to accept the original Treaty]],<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1922/01/07/00003.asp#N243 Treaty debates 7 January 1922 c.345]</ref> and de Valera resigned as [[President of Dáil Éireann]].<ref>[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/dail/1922/01/09/00003.asp Treaty debates 9 January 1922 cc.349–380]</ref> In the [[Irish Civil War]], he was nominal leader of the anti-Treaty side, although the military force was led by republicans who regarded external association as an unacceptable compromise. In June 1922, UK prime minister [[David Lloyd George]] sought clarification from the pro-Treaty [[Provisional Government of Ireland (1922)|Provisional Government]] that was drafting the [[Constitution of the Irish Free State]]; one question was:<ref name="jstor30008695p396">{{cite journal|last=O'Grady|first=Joseph P.|date=November 1989|title=The Irish Free State Passport and the Question of Citizenship, 1921-4|journal=Irish Historical Studies|publisher=Cambridge University Press|volume=26|issue=104|pages=396–405: 397 |jstor=30008695}}</ref> :Is it intended by the Irish representatives that the I.F.S. shall be within the empire on the basis of common citizenship, or merely associated with it? [[Arthur Griffith]]'s answer was:<ref name="jstor30008695p396"/> :it is intended that the Irish Free State shall be, not merely associated with, but a member of and within the Community of nations known as the British Empire and on the basis of common citizenship as explicitly provided by the Treaty
The pro-Treaty [[Cumann na nGaedheal]] party formed the [[Executive Council of the Irish Free State]] until 1932 and participated in the Commonwealth's [[Imperial Conference]]s.
==1930s developments== {{see also|Executive Authority (External Relations) Act 1936|Irish head of state from 1936 to 1949}} De Valera's [[Fianna Fáil]] party, founded in 1926, came to power in the Free State after the [[Irish general election, 1932|1932 general election]] and proceeded to eliminate many of the symbols of the state's Dominion status, including the [[Oath of Allegiance (Ireland)|Oath of Allegiance]]<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1933/en/act/pub/0006/ Constitution (Removal of Oath) Act, 1933] [[Irish Statute Book]]</ref> and appeal to the [[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council]].<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1933/en/act/pub/0045/print.html Constitution (Amendment No. 22) Act, 1933] Irish Statute Book</ref> Although this implicitly abrogated the 1921 Treaty, the Privy Council ruled in 1935 that the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]] empowered the Free State government to do so.<ref name="mooreDecision">{{cite web|url=http://www.supremecourt.ie/supremecourt/sclibrary3.nsf/(WebFiles)/34740D4947655F668025765E0036AE51/$FILE/Moore%20v%20AG_1935.rtf|title=Moore -v- Attorney General of the Irish Free State|work=Important Judgments|publisher=Courts Service|accessdate=2 November 2010|location=Dublin}}</ref>
The [[Constitution (Amendment No. 27) Act 1936]] abolished the office of [[Governor-General of the Irish Free State|Governor-General]] and removed all [[Monarchy in the Irish Free State|references to the monarch]] from the constitution, with most functions reassigned to [[Executive Council of the Irish Free State|the Executive Council]].<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1936/en/act/pub/0057/ Constitution (Amendment No. 27) Act, 1936] Irish Statute Book</ref> However, the [[Executive Authority (External Relations) Act 1936]], passed immediately afterwards, effected that the king continued to be head of state for external purposes, including [[treaty|treaties]] and [[Diplomatic accreditation|accrediting diplomats]].<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1936/en/act/pub/0058/ Executive Authority (External Relations) Act, 1936] Irish Statute Book</ref> In 1937, [[Constitution of Ireland|a new constitution]] came into effect. This made no mention of the British Commonwealth or monarchy, and established the office of [[President of Ireland]] with many of the internal functions of a head of state, including [[order of precedence|precedence]], [[pardon]], [[signing into law|signing laws]], and appointing [[Cabinet (government)|ministers]], [[Courts of the Republic of Ireland#Judges|judges]], and [[officer (armed forces)|military officers]]. Nevertheless, the External Relations Act remained in force by virtue of the Constitution's allusion to the British monarch in Article 29.4.2°:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/en/constitution/index.html#article29_4_2 |nopp=Y |title=Constitution of Ireland|date=1 November 2013|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|pages=Article 29.4.2°|accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |isbn=0707624401 |format=PDF |url=https://www.constitution.ie/Documents/Constitutional%20Review%20Group%201996.pdf#page=96 |title=Report |last=Constitution Review Group |series=Official publications |volume=Pn.2632 |year=1996 |publisher=Stationery Office |nopp=Y |pages=Article 29.4 |accessdate=24 July 2015 |location=Dublin}}</ref> : For the purpose of the exercise of any executive function of the State in or in connection with its external relations, the Government may to such extent and subject to such conditions, if any, as may be determined by law, avail of or adopt any organ, instrument, or method of procedure used or adopted for the like purpose by the members of any group or league of nations with which the State is or becomes associated for the purpose of international co-operation in matters of common concern.
Commentators have compared this situation, where the President was the de facto internal head of state while the King was the de jure external head of state, with de Valera's 1920s external association proposal.<ref>Mansergh 1991, Chapter 14</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=McMahon|first=Deirdre|date=September 1981|title='A Transient Apparition': British Policy towards the de Valera Government, 1932-5|journal=Irish Historical Studies|volume=22|issue=88|pages=331–361|jstor=30006731}}</ref><ref name="Smith1949">{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=S. A.|year=1949|title=The London Declaration of the Commonwealth prime ministers, April 28, 1949|journal=The Modern Law Review|volume=12|issue=3|pages=351–354|issn=0026-7961|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2230.1949.tb00131.x}}</ref><ref name="Mair1978">{{cite journal|last=Mair|first=Peter|year=1978|title=The break‐up of the United Kingdom: The Irish experience of regime change, 1918–1949|journal=The Journal of Commonwealth & Comparative Politics|volume=16|issue=3|pages=288–302|issn=0306-3631|doi=10.1080/14662047808447315}}</ref> While he had made "a republic in all but name", De Valera avoided explicitly declaring a republic, which he believed would alienate the [[Unionism in Ireland|Unionist]] majority in [[Northern Ireland]] and thus entrench [[Partition of Ireland|Partition]].<ref name="BrennanGoldring1986">{{cite book|editor1-last=Brennan|editor1-first=Paul|editor2-last=Goldring|editor2-first=Maurice|editor3-last=Deutsch|editor3-first=Richard|first=John |last=Bowman|title=Eamon de Valera|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=EIqLiopKPtIC&pg=PA38|accessdate=18 August 2012|date=1 January 1986|publisher=Presses Sorbonne Nouvelle|isbn=9782903019600|page=38|chapter=De Valera: Did he entrench the partition of Ireland?}}</ref> Ireland took no part in Commonwealth business; whether it remained a member of the Commonwealth or merely associated with it was a moot point.<ref>Mansergh 1991, p.328</ref> De Valera told the Dáil in 1945:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail1945071700022#N16|title=Committee on Finance. - Vote 65—External Affairs.|date=17 July 1945|work=Dáil Éireann debates|publisher=Oireachtas|pages=Vol. 97 No. 23 p.22 cc.2569–73|nopp=Y|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> :[[James Dillon (Fine Gael politician)|Deputy [James] Dillon]] ... asked was this State a republic, and were we a member State of the British Commonwealth. ... The position, as I conceive it to be, is this: We are an independent republic, associated as a matter of our external policy with the States of the British Commonwealth. To mark this association, we avail ourselves of the procedure of the External Relations Act ..., by which the King recognised by the States of the British Commonwealth therein named acts for us, under advice, in certain specified matters in the field of our external relations. :And now, to Deputy Dillon's second question—are we or are we not a member of the British Commonwealth? That is a question for which the material necessary for a conclusive answer is not fully available. It depends on what the essential element is in the constitution of the British Commonwealth. By contrast, Nicholas Mansergh wrote in 1948, "External association has never been put into practice because the United Kingdom and the oversea dominions have never recognized that it exists."<ref>Mansergh 1997, p.161</ref>
==Republic of Ireland and London Declaration== Fianna Fáil lost power [[Irish general election, 1948|in 1948]], and [[Government of the 13th Dáil|the Inter-Party Government]]'s [[Republic of Ireland Act 1948]], which came into force in 1949, repealed the External Relations Act and declared the Irish state to be a republic, implicitly leaving the Commonwealth. With the prospect of [[Dominion of India|newly independent India]] also [[Republic Day (India)|declaring a republic]], the Commonwealth leaders agreed in the [[London Declaration]] of 28 April 1949 that republics could be members of the Commonwealth, while the British monarch would remain [[Head of the Commonwealth]]. The situation where the monarch was head of the association but not necessarily of its members has been compared to de Valera's external association.<ref name="McIntyre1999">{{cite journal|last=McIntyre|first=W. David|year=1999|title=The strange death of dominion status|journal=The Journal of Imperial and Commonwealth History|volume=27|issue=2|pages=193–212|issn=0308-6534|doi=10.1080/03086539908583064}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Mansergh|first=Nicholas|date=July 1952|title=Ireland: The Republic Outside the Commonwealth|journal=International Affairs|publisher=Royal Institute of International Affairs; Wiley-Blackwell|volume=28|issue=3|pages=277–291|jstor=2607413|doi=10.2307/2607413}}</ref><ref name="Mcintyre2002">{{cite journal|last=Mcintyre|first=W. David|year=2002|title='A formula may have to be found': Ireland, India, and the headship of the Commonwealth|journal=The Round Table|volume=91|issue=365|pages=391–413|issn=0035-8533|doi=10.1080/00358530220138578}}</ref>
