States of)}}{{UN_Population|ref}} | population_estimate_year = {{UN_Population|Year}} | population_estimate_rank = 192nd | population_density_km2 = 158.1 | population_density_rank = 75th | population_density_sq_mi = 409.6 | GDP_PPP = $342 million | GDP_PPP_year = 2017 | GDP_PPP_rank = | GDP_PPP_per_capita = $3,800 | GDP_PPP_per_capita_rank = | GDP_nominal = $329 million | GDP_nominal_year = 2017 | GDP_nominal_per_capita = $3,400 | Gini = 40.1 | Gini_year = 2013 | Gini_change = | Gini_ref = {{cite web|title=GINI index|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.GINI?order=wbapi_data_value_2002+wbapi_data_value+wbapi_data_value-last&sort=asc&page=2|publisher=World Bank|accessdate=26 July 2013}} | Gini_rank = | HDI = 0.638 | HDI_year = 2015 | HDI_change = increase | HDI_ref = {{cite web |url = http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/2016_human_development_report.pdf |title = 2016 Human Development Report |date=2016 |accessdate = 21 March 2017 |publisher=United Nations Development Programme }} | HDI_rank = 127th | currency = [[United States dollar]] | currency_code = USD | time_zone = | utc_offset = +10 and +11 | utc_offset_DST = | time_zone_DST = ''not observed'' | date_format = MM/DD/YYYY | drives_on = right | calling_code = [[+691]] | iso3166code = FM | cctld = [[.fm]] | footnote_a = Regional languages used at state and municipal levels. }} The '''Federated States of Micronesia''' ({{IPAc-en|audio=en-us-Micronesia.ogg|ˌ|m|aɪ|k|r|oʊ|ˈ|n|iː|ʒ|ə}}; abbreviated '''FSM''' and also known simply as '''Micronesia''') is an independent republic [[associated state|associated to]] the [[United States]]. It consists of four [[Federal state|states]]{{spaced ndash}} from west to east, [[Yap State|Yap]], [[Chuuk State|Chuuk]], [[Pohnpei State|Pohnpei]] and [[Kosrae State|Kosrae]]{{spaced ndash}}that are spread across the [[Western Pacific Ocean]]. Together, the states comprise around 607 islands (a combined [[land area]] of approximately {{convert|702|km2|abbr=on|disp=or}}) that cover a [[Longitude|longitudinal]] distance of almost {{convert|2700|km|0|abbr=on}} just north of the [[equator]]. They lie northeast of [[New Guinea]], south of [[Guam]] and the [[Marianas]], west of [[Nauru]] and the [[Marshall Islands]], east of [[Palau]] and the [[Philippines]], about {{convert|2900|km|0|abbr=on}} north of eastern [[Australia]] and some {{convert|4000|km|0|abbr=on}} southwest of the main islands of [[Hawaii]]. While the FSM's total land area is quite small, it occupies more than {{convert|2600000|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} of the [[Pacific Ocean]], giving the country the 14th largest [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] in the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2016/01/daily-chart-10?fsrc=scn/fb/wl/bl/dc/st/dropsintheocean|title=Drops in the ocean: France’s marine territories|publisher=}} The independent [[Sovereign state|sovereign]] [[Island country|island nation]]s capital is [[Palikir]], located on [[Pohnpei Island]], while the largest city is [[Weno]], located in the [[Chuuk Atoll]]. Each of its four states is centered on one or more main [[high island]]s, and all but Kosrae include numerous outlying [[atoll]]s. The Federated States of Micronesia is spread across part of the [[Caroline Islands]] in the wider region of [[Micronesia]], which consists of thousands of small islands divided among several countries. The term ''Micronesia'' may refer to the Federated States or to the region as a whole. The FSM was formerly a part of the [[Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands]] (TTPI), a [[United Nations]] Trust Territory under U.S. administration, but it formed its own constitutional government on May 10, 1979, becoming a sovereign state after independence was attained on November 3, 1986 under a [[Compact of Free Association]] with the United States. Other neighboring island entities, and also former members of the TTPI, formulated their own constitutional governments and became the [[Marshall Islands|Republic of the Marshall Islands]] (RMI) and the [[Palau|Republic of Palau]] (ROP). The FSM has a seat in the United Nations. ==History== {{Main|History of the Federated States of Micronesia}} {{Quote box |title=Historical affiliations |quote={{flag|Spain|1785}} 1565–1899
{{flagcountry|German Empire}} 1899–1918
{{flagcountry|Empire of Japan}} 1919–1947
{{flag|United States|1960}} 1947–1994
{{flag|Micronesia}} 1994–present |align=left |width=22em |fontsize=90% |bgcolor=#B0C4DE }} The ancestors of the Micronesians settled over four thousand years ago. A decentralized chieftain-based system eventually evolved into a more centralized economic and religious culture centered on [[Yap Island]]. [[Nan Madol]], consisting of a series of small [[artificial island]]s linked by a network of canals, is often called the Venice of the Pacific. It is located on the eastern periphery of the island of Pohnpei and used to be the ceremonial and political seat of the Saudeleur dynasty that united Pohnpei's estimated 25,000 people from about [[Anno Domini|AD]] 500 until 1500, when the centralized system collapsed. European explorers—first the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] in search of the [[Maluku Islands|Spice Islands]] ([[Indonesia]]) and then the [[Spanish Empire|Spanish]]—reached the [[Caroline Islands|Carolines]] in the sixteenth century. The Spanish incorporated the archipelago to the [[Spanish East Indies]] through the capital, [[Manila]], and in the 19th century established a number of outposts and missions. In 1887, they founded the town of ''Santiago de la Ascension'' in what today is [[Kolonia]] on the island of Pohnpei. Following defeat in the [[Spanish–American War]], the Spanish sold the archipelago to [[German Empire|Germany]] in 1899 under the [[German–Spanish Treaty (1899)|German–Spanish Treaty of 1899]]. Germany incorporated it into [[German New Guinea]]. During [[World War I]], it was captured by [[Empire of Japan|Japan]]. Following the war, the [[League of Nations]] awarded a [[League of Nations Mandate|mandate]] for Japan to administer the islands as part of the [[Nanyo (Japanese mandated territory)|South Pacific Mandate]]. During [[World War II]], a significant portion of the Japanese fleet was based in [[Truk Lagoon]]. In February 1944, [[Operation Hailstone]], one of the most important naval battles of the war, took place at Truk, in which many Japanese support vessels and aircraft were destroyed. Following World War II, it was administered by the [[United States]] under [[United Nations]] auspices in 1947 as part of the [[Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands]] pursuant to [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 21|Security Council Resolution 21]]. On May 10, 1979, four of the Trust Territory districts ratified a new constitution to become the Federated States of Micronesia. [[Palau]], the [[Marshall Islands]], and the [[Northern Mariana Islands]] chose not to participate. The FSM signed a [[Compact of Free Association]] with the United States, which entered into force on November 3, 1986, marking Micronesia's emergence from trusteeship to independence. Independence was formally concluded under international law in 1990, when the United Nations officially ended the Trusteeship status pursuant to [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 683|Security Council Resolution 683]]. The Compact was renewed in 2004. ==Politics== {{main|Politics of the Federated States of Micronesia}} The Federated States of Micronesia is governed by the [[Constitution of the Federated States of Micronesia|1979 constitution]], which guarantees fundamental human rights and establishes a separation of governmental powers. The unicameral Congress has fourteen members elected by popular vote. Four senators—one from each state—serve four-year terms; the remaining ten senators represent single-member districts based on population, and serve two-year terms. The President and Vice President are elected by Congress from among the four state-based senators to serve four-year terms in the executive branch. Their congressional seats are then filled by special elections. The president and vice president are supported by an appointed cabinet. There are no formal political parties. ===Defense and foreign affairs=== {{main|Compact of Free Association}} In international politics, the Federated States of Micronesia has often voted with the United States with respect to [[United Nations General Assembly]] resolutions.[https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/82642.pdf General Assembly - Overall Votes - Comparison with U.S. vote] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170626185544/https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/82642.pdf |date=June 26, 2017 }} lists Micronesia as in the country with the fourth high coincidence of votes. Micronesia has always been in the top four. The FSM is a sovereign, self-governing state in [[Associated state|free association]] with the [[United States|United States of America]], which is wholly responsible for its defense. The Division of Maritime Surveillance operates a paramilitary Maritime Wing and a small [[Water police|Maritime Police]] Unit. The Compact of Free Association allows [[nationality law of the Federated States of Micronesia|FSM citizens]] to join the U.S. military without having to obtain U.S. permanent residency or citizenship,{{cite web|url=http://www.us-army-info.com/pages/pdfs/enlistment_standards.pdf|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20081001231147/http://www.us-army-info.com/pages/pdfs/enlistment_standards.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-10-01|title=U.S. Military Enlistment Standards|publisher=}} allows for immigration and employment for Micronesians in the U.S., and establishes economic and technical aid programs. FSM has foreign relations with 56 countries, including the [[Holy See]]. FSM was admitted to the [[United Nations]] based on the [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]]'s recommendation on August 9, 1991 in Resolution 703 and the [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]]'s approval on September 17, 1991 in Resolution 46/2.[https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/46/2 United Nations General Assembly Resolution 46/2, ''Admission of the Federated States of Micronesia to Membership in the United Nations,'' adopted 17 September 1991.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903224742/http://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A%2FRES%2F46%2F2 |date=September 3, 2015 }} The FSM is an active member of the [[Pacific Islands Forum]].{{Cite web|title = Federated States of Micronesia|url = https://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/fsm|website = U.S. Department of the Interior|accessdate = 2016-12-02|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161023081319/https://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/fsm|archive-date = October 23, 2016|dead-url = no|df = mdy-all}} ===Administrative divisions=== [[File:Map of the Federated States of Micronesia CIA.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|A map of the Federated States of Micronesia.]] {{main|Administrative divisions of the Federated States of Micronesia}} The four states in the federation are, from west to east: {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- !rowspan="2"|Flag !rowspan="2"|States{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/fm.html|title=The World Factbook -- Central Intelligence Agency|last=|first=|date=|website=Cia World Factbook|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180807215908/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/fm.html|archive-date=7 August 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=8 August 2018}} !rowspan="2"|Capital !rowspan="2"|Current Governor !colspan="2"|Land !rowspan="2"|Population[http://www.fsmgov.org/info/people.html FSM government website - Population] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629052438/http://www.fsmgov.org/info/people.html |date=June 29, 2012 }} !colspan="2"|Population
density |- !km² !sq mi[http://www.fsmgov.org/info/geog.html FSM government website - Geography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030807/http://www.fsmgov.org/info/geog.html |date=March 4, 2016 }} !per km² !per sq mi |- |{{flagicon|Yap|size=50px}} || [[Yap State|Yap]] || [[Colonia, Yap|Colonia]] || [[Tony Ganangyan]] || 118.1 || 45.6 || align="right" | 16,436 ||94 || 243 |- |{{flagicon|Chuuk|size=50px}} || [[Chuuk State|Chuuk]] || [[Weno]] || [[Johnson Elimo]] || 127.4 || 49.2 ||align="right"| 54,595 || 420 || 1088 |- |{{flagicon|Pohnpei|size=50px}} || [[Pohnpei State|Pohnpei]] || [[Kolonia]] || [[Marcelo Peterson]] || 345.5 || 133.4 || align="right" | 34,685 || 98 || 255 |- |{{flagicon|Kosrae|size=50px}} || [[Kosrae State|Kosrae]] || [[Tofol]] || [[Lyndon Jackson]] || 109.6 || 42.3 ||align="right"|7,686{{Cite web|url=http://www.fsmgov.org/info/people.html|title=FSM Population|website=www.fsmgov.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629052438/http://www.fsmgov.org/info/people.html|archivedate=June 29, 2012|df=mdy-all}}|| 66 || 170 |} These states are further divided into [[municipality|municipalities]]. ===Disputed sovereignty=== [[Spain]] has a claim to [[sovereignty]] over a few islands including [[Kapingamarangi]] in [[Pohnpei State]]. A commission of [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinals]] under [[Pope Leo XIII]] arbitrated a dispute for the [[Caroline Islands]] and others extending from the [[Equator]] to 11°N [[Latitude]] and from 133°E to 164°E [[Longitude]]. [[Germany]] and [[Spain]] on 17 December 1885 agreed in a [[treaty]] that they were a part of the [[Spanish East Indies]]. In 1899, Spain sold "las Carolinas" to Germany. Kapingamarangi is far south of the Carolines and the people are racially and culturally [[Polynesians|Polynesian]], not [[Micronesian people|Micronesian]] or [[Carolinian people|Carolinian]]. In 1948, Emilio Pastor Santos of the [[Spanish National Research Council]] found that the charts and maps up to 1899 had shown that Kapingamarangi and a few other islands had never been considered part of the Carolines, were not included in the description of the territory transferred to Germany and were never [[Cession|ceded]] by Spain; therefore, Spain retained [[sovereignty]]. In 1949, the Cabinet of Diplomatic Information of the Spanish [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (Spain)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] issued the following declaration:
"... The Ministry recognises that it is a certain fact and historic truth due to Article 3 of the Treaty of July 1, 1899, that Spain reserved a series of rights in Micronesia and for another thing, the specifications of the territories which Spain ceded in 1899 leaves apart certain groups of islands in the same zone."
Successive Spanish governments have not abandoned Spain's sovereignty, or insisted on enforcing it, or recognized the sovereignty of the Federated States of Micronesia over Kapingamarangi.Pastor y Santos, Emilio ''Territorios de Soberanía española en Oceanía'', Instituto de Estudios Africanos, CSIC, Madrid, 1950Weaver, Zay ''Territories under Spanish Sovereignty in Oceania'' (partial translation of Pastor y Santos, Emilio ''Territorios de Soberanía española en Oceanía''), Palau Museum, Koror, 1967 The Federated States of Micronesia claims sovereignty and has [[de facto]] control of the island. ==Geography== [[File:Koloniasokehs.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|A view of Kolonia Town from Sokehs Ridge in [[Pohnpei]].]] {{main|Geography of the Federated States of Micronesia}} The Federated States of Micronesia consists of 607 [[island]]s extending {{convert|2900|km|0|abbr=on}} across the [[archipelago]] of the [[Caroline Islands]] east of the [[Philippines]]. The islands have a combined area of {{convert|702|km2|0|abbr=on}}. The islands are grouped into four states, which are [[Yap State|Yap]], [[Chuuk State|Chuuk]] (called Truk until January 1990), [[Pohnpei State|Pohnpei]] (known as "Ponape" until November 1984), and [[Kosrae]] (formerly Kusaie). These four states are each represented by a white star on the national flag. The capital is [[Palikir]], on Pohnpei. ==Transportation== The Federated States of Micronesia is served by four international airports. * [[Pohnpei International Airport]], on the main island of [[Pohnpei State]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/pohnpei.html|title=Federated States Of Micronesia (FSM) Division of Civil Aviation l Pohnpei International Airport (PNI) (PTPN), Pohnpei Island, Micronesia|last=|first=|date=7 August 2018|website=Federated States of Micronesia Division of Civil Aviation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180808032630/http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/pohnpei.html|archive-date=8 August 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=7 August 2018}} * [[Chuuk International Airport]], located on the main island of [[Chuuk State]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/chuuk.html|title=Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) Division of Civil Aviation l Chuuk International Airport (TKK) (PTKK) Weno Island, Micronesia|last=|first=|date=7 August 2018|website=Federated States of Micronesia Division of Civil Aviation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180808033120/http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/chuuk.html|archive-date=8 August 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=7 August 2018}} * [[Kosrae International Airport]], located on the main island of [[Kosrae State]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/kosrae.html|title=Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) Division of Civil Aviation l Kosrae International Airport (KSA) (PTSA) , Kosrae Island, Micronesia|last=|first=|date=7 August 2018|website=Federated States of Micronesia Division of Civil Aviation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180808033533/http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/kosrae.html|archive-date=8 August 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=7 August 2018}} * [[Yap International Airport]], located on the main island of [[Yap State]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/yap.html|title=Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) Division of Civil Aviation l Yap International Airport (YAP) (PTYA), Wa'ab, Micronesia|last=|first=|date=7 August 2018|website=Federated States of Micronesia Department of Civil Aviation|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180808034020/http://www.ict.fm/civilaviation/yap.html|archive-date=8 August 2018|dead-url=|access-date=7 August 2018}} ==Economy== {{main|Economy of the Federated States of Micronesia}} Economic activity in the Federated States of Micronesia consists primarily of [[subsistence farming]] and [[fishing]]. The islands have few mineral deposits worth exploiting, except for high-grade [[phosphate]]. [[longline fishing|Long line]] fishing of [[tuna]] is also viable with foreign vessels from [[China]] that operated in the 1990s. The potential for a [[tourist industry]] exists, but the remoteness of the location and a lack of adequate facilities hinder development. [[United States foreign aid|Financial assistance from the U.S.]] is the primary source of revenue, with the U.S. pledged to spend $1.3 billion in the islands in 1986–2001;{{update inline|date=June 2016}} the [[The World Factbook|CIA World Factbook]] lists high dependence on U.S. aid as one of the main concerns of the FSM. Geographical isolation and a poorly developed infrastructure are major impediments to long-term growth.{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/special-rep/ohrlls/sid/SIDS-states/profiles/fed_st_micronesia.htm |title=Federated States of Micronesia |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=17 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121130043513/http://www.un.org/special-rep/ohrlls/sid/SIDS-states/profiles/fed_st_micronesia.htm |archivedate=November 30, 2012 |df= }} == Society == ===Demographics=== {{main|Demographics of the Federated States of Micronesia}} [[File:Ulithi-Dancers.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|People performing a welcome ceremony on [[Ulithi]] atoll.]] The indigenous population of the nation, which is predominantly Micronesian, consists of various ethnolinguistic groups. It has a nearly 100% Pacific Islander and [[Asian people|Asian]] population: [[Chuukese people|Chuukese]] 48.8%, [[Pohnpeian language|Pohnpeian]] 24.2%, [[Kosraean language|Kosraean]] 6.2%, [[Yapese people|Yapese]] 5.2%, [[Yap]] outer islands 4.5%, [[Asian ethnic groups|Asian]] 1.8%, [[Polynesians|Polynesian]] 1.5%, other 6.4%, unknown 1.4%. A sizeable minority also have some [[Japanese settlement in the Federated States of Micronesia|Japanese ancestry]], which is a result of intermarriages between Japanese settlers and Micronesians during the Japanese colonial period.[http://www.fsmgov.org/press/pr12120a.htm President Emanuel Mori Meets With Japan Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924015858/http://www.fsmgov.org/press/pr12120a.htm |date=September 24, 2015 }}; [http://www.aesonline.org/3056 AESonline.org] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070616091249/http://www.aesonline.org/3056 |date=June 16, 2007 }} Government of the Federated States of Micronesia, December 12, 2007 There is also a growing expatriate population of Americans, Australians, Europeans, and residents from China and the Philippines since the 1990s. [[English language|English]] has become the common language of the government, and for secondary and tertiary education. Outside of the main capital towns of the four FSM states, the local languages are primarily spoken. Population growth remains high at more than 3% annually, offset somewhat by net emigration. ===Languages=== English is the official and common language. Also spoken are [[Chuukese language|Chuukese]], [[Kosraean language|Kosraean]], [[Pohnpeian language|Pohnpeian]], [[Yapese language|Yapese]], [[Ulithian language|Ulithian]], [[Woleaian language|Woleaian]], [[Nukuoro language|Nukuoro]], and [[Kapingamarangi language|Kapingamarangi]]. Other languages spoken in the country include [[Pingelapese]], [[Ngatikese]], [[Satawalese language|Satawalese]], [[Puluwatese language|Puluwatese]], [[Mortlockese language|Mortlockese]], and [[Mokilese language|Mokilese]].{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} There are about 3,000 speakers of Kapingamarangi and [[Ulithian language|Ulithian]], and under 1,000 speakers of [[Nukuoro language|Nukuoro]].{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} ===Religion=== {{main|Religion in the Federated States of Micronesia}} [[File:Operation Christmas Drop 2008 081219-F-6911G-440.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|The US Air Force has [[Operation Christmas Drop|dropped presents and humanitarian aid to the islands]] every Christmas since 1952.]] Most Micronesians are [[Christian]]. Several [[Protestant]] denominations, as well as the [[Roman Catholic (term)|Roman]] [[Catholic Church]], are present in every Micronesian state.[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90145.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2007: Micronesia, Federated States of] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113040223/http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90145.htm |date=January 13, 2012 }}. United States [[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor]] (September 14, 2007). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].'' Most Protestant groups trace their roots to American Congregationalist missionaries. On the island of Kosrae, the population is approximately 7,800; 95 percent are Protestants. On [[Pohnpei]], the population of 35,000 is evenly divided between Protestants and Catholics. Most immigrants are Filipino Catholics who have joined local Catholic churches, e.g. Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church in Pohnpei. On Chuuk and Yap, an estimated 60 percent are Catholic and 40 percent are Protestant. Religious groups with small followings include [[Baptists]], [[Assemblies of God]], [[Salvation Army]], [[Seventh-day Adventists]], [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (Mormons), and the [[Bahá'í Faith]]. There is a small group of [[Buddhists]] on Pohnpei, and a small group of [[Ahmadiyya|Ahmadiyya Muslims]] in Kosrae. Attendance at religious services is generally high; [[church (building)|churches]] are well supported by their congregations and play a significant role in civil society. In the 1890s, on the island of Pohnpei, intermissionary conflicts and the conversion of clan leaders resulted in religious divisions along clan lines which persist today. More Protestants live on the western side of the island, while more Catholics live on the eastern side. [[Missionaries]] of many religious traditions are present and operate freely. The Constitution provides for [[freedom of religion]], and the Government generally respected this right in practice. The US government received no reports of societal abuses or discrimination based on religious belief or practice in 2007. === Health === See [[Health in the Federated States of Micronesia]] == Sport == {{Main|Category:Sports in the Federated States of Micronesia}} === Football === The [[sport]] of [[Association football|football]] in the Federated States of Micronesia is run by the [[Federated States of Micronesia Football Association]]. They control the [[Micronesian Games|Micronesian games]], the nation's football championship and the [[Federated States of Micronesia national football team|Micronesia National Football Team]]. === FSMAA === [[Federated States of Micronesia Athletic Association|The Federated States of Micronesia Athletic Association]] is the governing body for the country's [[Sport|sports]] and athletics.[[File:Yap Stone Money.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|A large (approximately 2.4 m or about 8 ft in height) example of Yapese stone money ([[Rai stones]]) in the village of Gachpar.]] ==Culture== {{see also|Music of the Federated States of Micronesia}} Each of the four states has its own culture and traditions, but there are also common cultural and economic bonds that are centuries old. Cultural similarities include the importance of the traditional extended family and clan systems and are found on all the islands. The island of Yap is notable for its "stone money" ([[Rai stones]]), large disks usually of calcite, up to {{convert|4|m|ft|sp=us}} in diameter, with a hole in the middle. The islanders, aware of the owner of a piece, do not necessarily move them when ownership changes. There are five major types: ''Mmbul'', ''Gaw'', ''Ray'', ''Yar'', and ''Reng'', the last being only {{convert|30|cm|0|abbr=on}} in diameter. Their value is based on both size and history, many of them having been brought from other islands, as far as [[New Guinea]], but most coming in ancient times from [[Palau]]. Approximately 6,500 of them are scattered around the island. Pohnpei is home to ''[[Nan Madol]]: Ceremonial Centre of Eastern Micronesia'', a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]], but the site is currently listed as ''In Danger'' due to natural causes.{{Cite web|url=https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1503|title=Nan Madol: Ceremonial Centre of Eastern Micronesia - UNESCO World Heritage Centre|last=|first=|date=7 August 2018|website=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180807221707/https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1503|archive-date=7 August 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=7 August 2018}} The government is working on the conservation of the site. ===Literature=== There have been very few published literary writers from the Federated States of Micronesia.[http://guam.mvarietynews.com/index.php?view=article&id=4591%3Aseeking-micronesian-literary-writers&option=com_content&Itemid=2 "Seeking Micronesian literary writers"], ''Marianas Variety'', February 18, 2009 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140928150350/http://guam.mvarietynews.com/index.php?view=article&id=4591%3Aseeking-micronesian-literary-writers&option=com_content&Itemid=2 |date=September 28, 2014 }} In 2008, [[Emelihter Kihleng]] became the first ever Micronesian to publish a collection of poetry in the English language.[http://www.doi.gov/oia/press/2008/05122008b.html "Micronesian Poet Publishes Collection of Poems"], Office of Insular Affairs, May 12, 2008 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229151437/http://www.doi.gov/oia/press/2008/05122008b.html |date=February The '''''Finnish Trade Register''''' ({{lang-fi|'''Kaupparekisteri'''}}, {{lang-sv|'''Handelsregistret'''}}) is a [[company register]] in [[Finland]]. It provides official information on businesses in the whole country, including data from current and old register entries, articles of association, partnership agreements or rules.
== Registrar ==
The register is maintained by the [[:fi:Patentti-_ja_rekisterihallitus|Finnish Patent and Registration Office]].
== Content ==
The content of the Trade Register is specified by Finnish law.
=== Identifier ===
When a start-up notification is filed with the Trade Register or the Register of Foundations, the new business or foundation receives its Business ID ({{lang-fi|'''Y-tunnus''', Yritys- ja yhteisötunnus}}, {{lang-sv|'''FO-nummer''', Företags- och organisationsnumret}}).
== Public availability ==
The particulars reported by a company in its notice to the Trade Register and the documents attached to the notice are all public information.
== Purpose ==
=== Provider of legal documents ===
The Trade Register also delivers certificates. For example, a certificate from the book of original entries verifies that a notice has been submitted to the Register.
== Similar registers ==
Another set of [[company registers]] is maintained by [[Statistics Finland]]. They are called '''Register of Enterprises and Establishments''', '''Register of Public Corporations''' and '''Enterprise Group Register'''. Their purpose is to sell statistical information.
==See also== *[[List of company registers]]
== External links == * [http://www.prh.fi/en/kaupparekisteri.html National Board of Patents and Registration of Finland - Trade Register] *Further details of the Business ID can be found on the [https://www.ytj.fi/english/business-id Finnish Business Information System], which is jointly maintained by the National Board of Patents and Registration (NBPR) and the Tax Administration.

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox Radio Show | show_name = The Gascony Show | image = Gascony_Show_Logo.jpg | imagesize = 150px | caption = | other_names = | format = [[Talk show|Talk]] | runtime = Sundays 5pm-7pm [[Central European Time|CET]] | country = France | language = English | home_station = Radio Coteaux | syndicates = | television = | starring = John Slattery | creator = | writer = | director = | producer = Patrick Martinez | newsreader = | sportreader = | executive_producer = | narrated = | record_location = Radio Coteaux Studios, [[Saint-Blancard]] | first_aired = 10 July 2011 | last_aired = | num_series = | num_episodes = | audio_format = FM and Digital radio | opentheme = | endtheme = | website = [http://www.gasconyshow.com Official website] | podcast = [http://www.gasconyshow.com/podcasts/GasconyShowPodcasts.xml Official podcast] }}
The '''''Gascony Show''''' is an English-language radio [[chat show]] aired in the southwest of France and a flagship Sunday evening programme broadcast on [[Radio Coteaux]]<ref name=radiocoteaux1774922>[http://www.radiocoteaux.com/emissionsthematiques.php "Emissions thématiques sur le site officiel de radio coteaux, frequences 104.4 et 97.7 FM"] By Patrick Martinez, Radio Coteaux</ref> in the [[Gascony]] region. The show is presented by Irishman John Slattery.
==The show== [[File:John Slattery Gascony Show.jpg|thumb|left|alt=John Slattery, the Gascony Show host in the radio studio.|''The Gascony Show'' host, John Slattery, in the studio in Saint Blancard]] John Slattery takes over the airwaves at 5pm and finishes at 7pm with a handover to Patrick Martinez. The ''Gascony Show'' is a music-based programme that includes light-hearted banter and whimsical jokes by the host. Listeners' views and comments are discussed and there are rotating segments such as "Song of The Week" and "Life in the South-West". To keep listeners on their toes, random topics are picked from a big "Bag O Topics."
Podcasts of all previous shows<ref name=gasconyshow5436793>[http://www.gasconyshow.com/podcasts/GasconyShowPodcasts.xml "The Gascony Show Podcasts"] Recordings of all previous shows.</ref> are available on the show's website so that previous shows can be listened to again. Previous shows can also be found on iTunes.<ref name=gasconyshow5434434>[https://itunes.apple.com/fr/podcast/the-gascony-show/id455503319 "The Gascony Show on iTunes"] Recordings of all previous shows.</ref>
==Invited guests==
The show runs interviews with regular and/or rotating guests,<ref name=gasconyshow2334923>[http://www.gasconyshow.com/archives.html "The Gascony Show Archives"] Recorded shows with guests.</ref> dealing with subjects of both local interest and of general interest to the [[expatriate]] community. The first person to be interviewed on the show was the illustrious English painter, interior designer and writer, Stella Wulf.<ref name=gasconyshow2345213>[http://web.me.com/claire.jefferson/StellaWulf/StopPress.html "Stella Wulf, News & Events"] Interview, Sunday, 10 July 2011.</ref> Stella is the author of "The Lonesome Froom and other Strange Tales," "Rum Rhymes and Vagabond" and "The Song of the Froom." She recounted humorous stories of her years in France and her efforts to get her books published.
Subsequent interviews included music industry notaries such as Joy Askew and her brother Roger Askew.<ref name=pkmediapromotions6456442>[https://www.youtube.com/user/PKMediaPromotions "The Gascony Show Channel"] Produced by PK Media Promotions.</ref> These two truly multi-dimensional singers sang some of their favourite songs on air. Joy, who worked closely with the likes of [[Peter Gabriel]] and Joe Jackson, and fronted the all-girl rock band called Bitch, told her story of life as a song-writer and touring musician. The interview proved enormously popular with both English and French speaking listeners in France and it served to create a pattern of story telling and musical treats that would become an underlying trait of later interviews.
A highly commended interview was that with Leaf Fielding,<ref name=leaffielding5437658>[http://www.leaffielding.com/news.html "Leaf Fielding on the Gascony Show"] Interview, Sunday, 11 September 2011.</ref> one of the drug-dealers jailed as a result of the famous 1977 drug cartel bust in the UK called [[Operation Julie]]. The interview revolved around Leaf's life, his descent into drug dealing, his imprisonment, and his new life in France. Also discussed was Leaf’s book ''To Live Outside The Law'',<ref name=leaffielding1116349>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jul/07/leaf-fielding-outside-law-drugs "To Live Outside The Law"] By The Guardian, Thursday, 7 July 2011.</ref> that tells the story from his early days and his first experience with LSD, to his amazing falling from grace.
==Regular contributors==
The show relies heavily on e-mailed material sent in by listeners that is then read out on air, and most of the regular contributors are local [[expatriates]] living in the Gascony region.

It was established and started operations in 1985 and operated domestic charter flights. '''Gyeonggi Broadcasting Corporation''' ({{korean|hangul=경기방송|hanja=京畿放送}}) is a [[broadcasting]] company headquartered in [[Suwon]], [[Gyeonggi]], [[Korea]], established in 1997. It is an [[FM Radio]] broadcaster in [[Seoul]], [[Incheon]], [[Gyeonggi]], tele number is KFM, [[frequency]] is 99.9 [[megahertz|MHz]], over power from 5 [[kilowatt|kW]] if similar broadcast network at [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation]], [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]], [[SBS (Korea)]].
== See also == * [[List of Korea-related topics]] * [[Communications in South Korea]] * [[Contemporary culture of South Korea]]
== External links == * [http://www.kfm.co.kr Gyeonggi Broadcasting Corporation] - Official Website (in Korean)

revision.text:
In the first branch of the [[Mabinogion]], '''Hefeydd Hen''' (or Heyfedd the Old{{cite web|title=Welsh-English Dictionary|url=https://glosbe.com/cy/en/hen|website=Glosbe|accessdate=25 August 2016}}) was the father of [[Rhiannon]].{{cite book|last=Davies|first=Sioned|title=The Mabinogion|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0199218783}} Hefeydd Hen, according to legend, tried to force his daughter Rhiannon to be married against her will to [[Gwawl]]. She met [[Pwyll]] of [[Dyfed]] and fell in love, planning to marry in one year and one day at his court on his estate. In accordance with the plan, they tried to marry but were thwarted by Clud and his son Gwawl. They put the wedding off for a further year. Pwyll and Rhiannon then went to Hefeydd’s court; he dressed as a beggar, asking for food. By a trick, Gwawl was captured and killed and Hefeydd was forced to allow Rhiannon to marry Pwyll in his court and then let her to return to [[Arberth]]. Heyfedd Hir (Hir meaning "long" in Welsh, but also referring to distance in time{{cite web|title=Welsh-English Dictionary|url=https://glosbe.com/cy/en/hir|website=Glosbe|accessdate=25 August 2016}}), is mentioned as one of the Seven Knights left to take charge of the Island of Britain when Bran went to rescue his sister in the second branch of the [[Mabinogion]]. He is also to be found in the 6th century epic poem [[Y Gododdin]] where the word "Hir" is used to describe no less than 7 individuals.{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Mary|title=Y Gododdin|url=http://www.maryjones.us/ctexts/a01a.html|website=Celtic Literature Collective|accessdate=24 August 2016}}
Caeawg, the leader, armed was he in the noisy conflict;
His was the foremost part of the advanced division, in front of the hosts.
Before his blades fell five battalions.
Of the men of Deivyr and Brenneich, uttering groans:
Twenty hundred perished in one hour.
Sooner did his flesh go to the wolf, than he to the nuptial feast;
He sooner became food for the raven, than approached the altar;
Before he entered the conflict of spears, his blood streamed to the ground.
It was the price of mead in the hall, amidst the throng.
Hyveidd Hir shall be celebrated as long as there will be a minstrel.
 Y Gododdin, stanza 5
==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Welsh mythology]] [[Category:Mabinogion]] {{Europe-myth-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Kivi-Tex | logo = | type = Private limited company | foundation = 1958 | founder = K.P. Thorgaard | location_city = [[Ballerup Municipality|Ballerup]], [[Copenhagen]] | location_country = [[Denmark]] | key_people = Eikemo Thorgård <small>([[chief executive officer|CEO]])</small>, Kristian Peter Thorgaard <small>([[chairman]])</small> | industry = Service | products = | services = B-to-B laundry, textile rentale | revenue = [[Danish krone|DKK]] 1.472 billion (2015)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business.dk/oekonomi/grafik-her-er-danmarks-1000-stoerste-virksomheder|title=Guld 1000 2016|language=Danish|publisher=Berlingske Business|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref> | net_income = | num_employees = 2,660<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business.dk/oekonomi/grafik-her-er-danmarks-1000-stoerste-virksomheder|title=Kuvu-tex|language=Danish|publisher=Berlingske Business|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref> | homepage = [http://www.dfd.dk/] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Kivi-Tex''' is a services company headquartered in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. It is the holding company of the textile services company '''De Forenede Dampvaskerier''' (DFD) and Elite Miljø.
==History== De Forenede Dampvaskerier was founded by Kristian Peter Thorgaard when he Lunds Lunds Kitteldepot in 1958.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business.dk/navne/53-familien-eikemo-thorgaard-omsaetning-rundede-15-mia.-kr|title=53 Familien Eikemo Thorgaard: Omsætning rundede 1,5 mia. kr.|publisher=Berlingske|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref> In 1961, he acquired another company, Kivi. The name of his company was changed to Kivi Kittel and later to Kivi-Tex.
Kivi-Tex acquired Danish service company Elite Miljø in 2004. In 2017, it acquired Swedish textile services company Textilia from Accent Equity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dfd.dk/om-dfd/textilia|title=Lavare Holding gets a new owner – Accent Equity divests to De Forenede Dampvaskerier|website=dfd.dk|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref>
==Operations== De forenede Dampcaskerier operates 20 laundries in Scandinavia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finans.dk/live/erhverv/ECE9393426/dansk-vaskerikonge-i-svensk-gigantopkoeb/?ctxref=ext|title=Dansk vaskerikonge i svensk gigantopkøb|language=Danish|website=finans.dk|accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.dfd.dk/ De Forenede Dampvaskerier]

{{Infobox TV channel | name = New Television (NTV) | logofile = <!--NTV Mongolia.png--> | logosize = 130px | logoalt = | launch = 2006 | closed date = | share = | share as of = | share source = | owner = | slogan = | country = [[Mongolia]] | broadcast area = Nationwide | headquarters = [[Ulaanbaatar]], [[Mongolia]] | former names = | replaced names = | sister names =ONTV | timeshift names = | picture format=[[HDTV]] ([[1080i]]) | web = http://www.ntv.mn/ |iptv serv 1=Univision|iptv chan 1=Channel 8 (HD)|iptv serv 2=Skymedia|iptv chan 2=Channel 3 (HD)|sat serv 1=Ddish|sat chan 1=Channel 9 (SD)|cable serv 1=MNBC|cable chan 1=Channel 9 (SD)}} '''New Television''' ({{lang-mn|NTV Телевиз}}), or '''NTV''', is a [[television]] broadcaster in [[Mongolia]]. It was founded in 2006 and is currently employing about 70 people. Its TV broadcast is mostly in Mongolian with occasional shows in English including one of Mongolia's few English-speaking news teams.
NTV is the fourth most popular TV channel in Mongolia after MNB, UBS and Bolovsrol Television. It is also affiliated with Neo-Century Radio 107.00FM.
== Sport broadcasting ==
The channel previously broadcast [[Bundesliga]] and [[Premier League]] highlights. It regularly broadcasts [[Mongolia national football team|Mongolian national football team]] matches.
It was one of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] broadcasters.
It currently broadcasts [[UEFA Nations League]] matches.
==See also== *[[Media of Mongolia]] *[[Communications in Mongolia]]

page.title: The Cambridge History of Inner Asia

revision.text:
{{Infobox book series | name = ''The Cambridge History of Inner Asia'' | title_orig = | image = | image_caption = | author = [[Denis Sinor]] (Edited the 1st vol.)
[[Nicola Di Cosmo]], Allen J. Frank and [[Peter B. Golden]] (Edited the 2nd vol.) | illustrator = | cover_artist = | translator = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | genre = [[Asian history]] | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | pub_date = 1987 onwards | number_of_books=3 (2 published) | english_pub_date = | media_type = | preceded by = | followed by = }} '''''The Cambridge History of Inner Asia''''' is an ongoing series of history books published by [[Cambridge University Press]] (CUP) covering the early and modern history of [[Inner Asia]]n and [[Central Asia]]n peoples. The first volume titled "''The Cambridge History of Early Inner Asia''" was edited by Denis Sinor, a Distinguished [[Professor Emeritus]] of [[Central Asian Studies]] at the [[Department of Central Eurasian Studies (Indiana University)|Department of Central Eurasian Studies]] at [[Indiana University (Bloomington)|Indiana University]] in 1987 and published in 1990.{{cite web|last=Franke |first=Herbert |url=http://histories.cambridge.org/book?id=chol9780521243049_CHOL9780521243049 |title=The Cambridge History of Early Inner Asia edited by Denis Sinor |website=Histories.cambridge.org |date= |accessdate=2016-10-24}} This volume introduces the geographical setting of [[Central Asia]] and follows its history from the palaeolithic era to the rise of the [[Mongol Empire]] in the thirteenth century. The series' second volume, ''The Cambridge History of Inner Asia: The Chinggisid Age'', was published in 2009. Similar to the previous volume, a large group of international experts contributed to each chapter. This volume centres on the history and legacy of the Mongol World Empire founded by [[Genghis Khan]] and its successor states, including its impact upon the modern world.{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridge.org/gb/knowledge/isbn/item1172647/?site_locale=en_GB |title=The Cambridge History of Inner Asia | Regional and World History General Interest | Cambridge University Press |website=Cambridge.org |date=2015-05-27 |accessdate=2016-10-24}} The Cambridge History of Inner Asia: The Modern Age is set to be released in the near future.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120602032552/http://history.stanford.edu/crews_robert ] ==Contents== The volumes of the series are as follows: # ''Early Inner Asia'' (edited by Denis Sinor), (March 30, 1990). {{ISBN|978-0521243049}}. # ''The Chinggisid Age'' (edited by Nicola Di Cosmo, Allen J. Frank and Peter B. Golden), September 28, 2009. {{ISBN|978-0521849265}} # ''The Modern Age'' (edited by Annette Bohr and Edmund Herzig), forthcoming.{{cite web|url=http://www.chathamhouse.org/about-us/directory/70659 |title=Annette Bohr |publisher=Chatham House |date=2014-03-11 |accessdate=2016-10-24}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==See also== *''[[The Cambridge History of China]]'', especially volume 6, ''Alien Regimes and Border States, 907–1368'' {{Cambridge History series}} {{Italic title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cambridge History of Inner Asia, The}} [[Category:1987 books]] [[Category:Cambridge University Press books]] [[Category:History books about Asia]] [[Category:Asian studies]] [[Category:Inner Asia]]
